posts.name: Denis
posts.cooked:
Hi guys. I’m currently trying to use filterpy to fuse global april tag, odometry and gyro data into a single global pose. The thing is though I’ve been trying to figure out the correct way to do this but I’m not sure if what I’m doing is correct (hence, this post). Anyway, my pipeline so far is:

Odometry/AprilTags/Gyro measurements (global frame)

EKF predict step with the dt adjusted

get R for the appropriate sensor

set R[i, i] to huge value for non-existant values (gyro does not return a global position so we just insert [x=0, y=0, vx=…, vy=…, theta=…] with HUGE values in R for the x and y.

update step with a plain jacobian matrix (eye(5)) same for hx

Now Mr. ChatGPT tells me that it is bad practice to insert odometry and april tag data into the same filter because the two sensors will “fight” each other over the position. It suggested that I only insert velocity and theta for odometry in the predict step but I don’t know exactly what that means and how I should execute that properly. Have you guys noticed this and, if so, how did you fix it? Should I just insert the velocity and completely ignore the x and y pose of the odometry?

Also, another thing that I was wondering is if I should insert into the kalman filter in batches (as soon as I get all the req data so x,y,vx,vy,theta) or as soon as data arrives (the latter one seems the most reasonable but I’m just asking because I’m not sure).

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked:
At work so can’t do much digging but this is a good question and I always go here first for technical controls related questions

Controls Engineering in the FRC

Section 9.8 is all about EKF ( page 171 )

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Unless I’m missing something in the academic text, it doesn’t answer OP’s questions about which signals are worth passing to the filter.

My crude take is if you know which signals are better for certain things, only pass those things.

Velocity and theta are nearly directly measured by odometer, and should be pretty good. Position will drift substantially over time, but the cameras will give a better nominal position. The cameras won’t measure robot angle nearly as precisely as a good gyro as well.

posts.name: Denis
posts.cooked: Yeah. I understand that. The problem is that when I add BOTH odometry and April tag poses to the filter at their respective update times, the position jiggles a lot. Additionally, if one sensor measurement disappears for too long (lets say you stopped seeing april tags for 5 seconds), the estimate starts heavily drifting to the other sensor position observation (so in this example, the estimate would start to heavily drift to odometry position even if the robot doesn’t move at all). Up until now, I thought that that was normal and that I should just tune R. But, now, I’m not sure if maybe I have been doing something wrong.

posts.name: Tyler Veness

posts.name: Denis
posts.cooked: Ok cool this is great! I didn’t know that this was possible up until now.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
godbrigero:

The problem is that when I add BOTH odometry and April tag poses to the filter at their respective update times, the position jiggles a lot.

You could try adding bias estimate states for each position measurement, though this explodes the dimensionality of your filter and won’t necessarily converge depending on the relative weights you pick, interactions with the rest of the nonlinear model, and jitter in your sample rate.

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked:
Yeah, that’s pretty normal when it comes to disparate sensor readings. You should do some physical tests and find out what your sensor data sees vs what your camera data sees vs the reality of it. Using separate filters there is a good idea, for testing.

Part of the problem here is that even if the robot is still, nearly everything in the system has some form of drift, and I’ve no idea how well they’re compensating the low level signal to present the data to you. Kalman filters are great in general because they can help rectify situations like this (e.g., filtering out gyro drift because we have a magnetometer), but a big question is always “who’s the liar”.

Ideally for Kalman and EKF, you’d always be able to tell what sensor is lying at any given time and how much it’s lying. Then you’d weight it less inversely proportional to how much it was lying. But finding that out is harder to know. The filtering is a mathematical model and helps by sort of comparing things together in a weighted way. You might logically think “I can’t be moving even if the accelerometer says I’m moving if there’s no camera movement”. But on the flip side, your cameras are also inaccurate and have different forms of inaccuracy. A robot moving compared to the April tag can look an awful lot like the camera getting new image data and re-calculating the tag position.

Drifting towards one or the other isn’t as big of a deal if we’re already close to the correct version and all of our sensor data helps us drift closer. For example, you might find that acceleration of the robot tends to reduce the accuracy of the sensors and the vision is more accurate. If it stays still, it might be the opposite. At the end of the day, you need to test it and compare it with the actual real life physical position of the robot.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked:
You’re right.

However I wasn’t trying to answer the question per say. I just saw it at work and felt it was ‘something’ to start with. Considering at the time nobody else had replied.

Not to mention tyler has now replied to channel with a better answer than I could

posts.name: Denis
posts.cooked: Speaking of which, I tried inputting non square matrices (R) into the filterpy kalman filter insert method but it just throws out an error saying invalid matrix sizes. Theoretically speaking though, is this kind of like just setting the whole row to 0?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: Q must be symmetric positive semidefinite (all eigenvalues ≥ 0), and R must be symmetric positive definite (all eigenvalues > 0) because they represent the noise covariances of the model states and measurements respectively. They are symmetric because the covariance of x with y is the same as the covariance of y with x. The diagonal entries are the covariance of a variable with itself, which is just the variance. The matrices being symmetric implies they must also be square.
